## Skills
These skills are discovered at startup from multiple local sources. Each entry includes a name, description, and file path so you can open the source for full instructions.
- skill-creator: Guide for creating effective skills. This skill should be used when users want to create a new skill (or update an existing skill) that extends Codex's capabilities with specialized knowledge, workflows, or tool integrations. (file: C:/Users/krkna/.codex/skills/.system/skill-creator/SKILL.md)
- skill-installer: Install Codex skills into $CODEX_HOME/skills from a curated list or a GitHub repo path. Use when a user asks to list installable skills, install a curated skill, or install a skill from another repo (including private repos). (file: C:/Users/krkna/.codex/skills/.system/skill-installer/SKILL.md)
- Discovery: Available skills are listed in project docs and may also appear in a runtime "## Skills" section (name + description + file path). These are the sources of truth; skill bodies live on disk at the listed paths.
- Trigger rules: If the user names a skill (with `$SkillName` or plain text) OR the task clearly matches a skill's description, you must use that skill for that turn. Multiple mentions mean use them all. Do not carry skills across turns unless re-mentioned.
- Missing/blocked: If a named skill isn't in the list or the path can't be read, say so briefly and continue with the best fallback.
- How to use a skill (progressive disclosure):
  1) After deciding to use a skill, open its `SKILL.md`. Read only enough to follow the workflow.
  2) If `SKILL.md` points to extra folders such as `references/`, load only the specific files needed for the request; don't bulk-load everything.
  3) If `scripts/` exist, prefer running or patching them instead of retyping large code blocks.
  4) If `assets/` or templates exist, reuse them instead of recreating from scratch.
- Description as trigger: The YAML `description` in `SKILL.md` is the primary trigger signal; rely on it to decide applicability. If unsure, ask a brief clarification before proceeding.
- Coordination and sequencing:
  - If multiple skills apply, choose the minimal set that covers the request and state the order you'll use them.
  - Announce which skill(s) you're using and why (one short line). If you skip an obvious skill, say why.
- Context hygiene:
  - Keep context small: summarize long sections instead of pasting them; only load extra files when needed.
  - Avoid deeply nested references; prefer one-hop files explicitly linked from `SKILL.md`.
  - When variants exist (frameworks, providers, domains), pick only the relevant reference file(s) and note that choice.
- Safety and fallback: If a skill can't be applied cleanly (missing files, unclear instructions), state the issue, pick the next-best approach, and continue.

# Week 4 Implementation Plan: Pilot Deployment & Production Validation

**Date:** December 26, 2025
**Status:** dY"< READY TO EXECUTE
**Theme:** Deploy to Production, Monitor, Iterate
**Duration:** 7 days (5 business days)
**Roadmap Reference:** [12-Week Roadmap v10.0](../planning/ROADMAP_12_WEEK_V10.md) - Week 4

---

## Executive Summary

Week 4 marks the transition from development to production deployment. Building on Week 3's successful observability implementation and performance baselining, we will now deploy QoreLogic to a pilot workspace for real-world validation.

**Week 3 Achievements:**
- Ð“o. Observability stack complete (structured logging, Prometheus metrics, Grafana dashboard)
- Ð“o. Performance baselines established (all targets exceeded by 4-100x)
- Ð“o. Incident response playbooks and SLO definitions created
- Ð“o. 132/144 tests passing (91.7% pass rate)
- Ð“o. Technical debt resolved

**Week 4 Objectives:**
1. Deploy QoreLogic to an internal pilot workspace
2. Monitor real-world usage for 7 consecutive days
3. Collect user feedback and identify pain points
4. Fix critical bugs and performance issues
5. Validate acceptance criteria in production

---

## Success Criteria

Week 4 is successful when ALL of the following are met:

| Criterion | Target | Measurement Method |
|:----------|:-------|:------------------|
| **Deployment Stability** | Ð“%Ð­99% uptime (7 days) | Prometheus metrics |
| **Performance** | P95 latency <1s | Real-time dashboard |
| **Accuracy** | Catch rate Ð“%Ð­95% | Manual audit review |
| **User Satisfaction** | Ð“%Ð­7/10 on survey | Post-week survey |
| **Incident Management** | Zero P0 incidents | Incident log |
| **Feedback Quality** | Ð“%Ð­10 actionable items | User interviews |

---

---

## Track A: Deployment (Platform Engineering)

**Agent:** `platform-engineer`
**Duration:** Day 1-2 (12 hours)
**Dependencies:** None (can start immediately)
**Status:** dY"< Ready

### Objectives

1. Select and prepare pilot workspace
2. Deploy QoreLogic MCP server
3. Configure 4 agents (Scrivener, Sentinel, Judge, Overseer)
4. Onboard pilot team
5. Create deployment runbook

### Tasks

| ID | Task | Duration | Deliverable |
|:---|:-----|:---------|:------------|
| A1 | Select pilot workspace | 2h | Pilot workspace selected |
| A2 | Pre-deployment verification | 1h | Checklist completed |
| A3 | Deploy MCP server | 3h | Server running |
| A4 | Configure agents | 2h | Agents operational |
| A5 | Team onboarding | 3h | Team trained |
| A6 | Create runbook | 1h | Deployment docs |

### Detailed Task Breakdown

#### A1: Select Pilot Workspace (2h)

**Criteria for Pilot Selection:**
- Internal project (dogfooding)
- Active development (Ð“%Ð­5 commits/week)
- Python codebase (native Q-DNA support)
- Team size: 2-5 developers
- Stakeholder buy-in confirmed

**Evaluation Matrix:**

| Workspace Candidate | Activity | Size | Risk | Score |
|:-------------------|:---------|:-----|:-----|:------|
| TBD | TBD | TBD | TBD | TBD |

**Deliverable:** Selected workspace documented in `PILOT_WORKSPACE.md`

#### A2: Pre-Deployment Verification (1h)

**Checklist:**
- [ ] Test suite passing (target: 132/132 active tests)
- [ ] Prometheus metrics endpoint responding
- [ ] Grafana dashboard loading
- [ ] Alert rules validated
- [ ] Database schema up to date
- [ ] MCP server health check passing
- [ ] Ed25519 keys generated for 4 agents
- [ ] Rollback plan documented

**Deliverable:** Pre-flight checklist signed off

#### A3: Deploy MCP Server (3h)

**Deployment Steps:**

1. **Prepare Environment**
   ```bash
   # Navigate to pilot workspace
   cd /path/to/pilot/workspace

   # Clone Q-DNA
   git clone https://github.com/MythologIQ/Q-DNA.git
   cd Q-DNA/local_fortress

   # Install dependencies
   pip install -r requirements.txt
   ```

2. **Initialize Database**
   ```bash
   # Create ledger database
   python -m mcp_server.myth_soa_init

   # Verify schema
   sqlite3 ledger/qdna_soa_ledger.db ".schema"
   ```

3. **Generate Agent Identities**
   ```bash
   # Generate DIDs for 4 agents
   python -m mcp_server.identity_gen --agent scrivener
   python -m mcp_server.identity_gen --agent sentinel
   python -m mcp_server.identity_gen --agent judge
   python -m mcp_server.identity_gen --agent overseer
   ```

4. **Start MCP Server**
   ```bash
   # Launch server
   python qorelogic.py

   # Verify startup
   curl http://localhost:9090/health
   ```

5. **Verify Metrics**
   ```bash
   # Check Prometheus endpoint
   curl http://localhost:9090/metrics | grep qorelogic
   ```

**Deliverable:** Running MCP server with health checks passing

#### A4: Configure Agents (2h)

**Agent Configuration:**

Create `agents.json`:
```json
{
  "agents": [
    {
      "name": "Scrivener",
      "did": "did:myth:scrivener:...",
      "role": "documentation",
      "trust_tier": "CBT",
      "permissions": ["audit_claim", "log_event"]
    },
    {
      "name": "Sentinel",
      "did": "did:myth:sentinel:...",
      "role": "verification",
      "trust_tier": "KBT",
      "permissions": ["audit_code", "audit_claim"]
    },
    {
      "name": "Judge",
      "did": "did:myth:judge:...",
      "role": "enforcement",
      "trust_tier": "IBT",
      "permissions": ["log_penalty", "log_event"]
    },
    {
      "name": "Overseer",
      "did": "did:myth:overseer:...",
      "role": "governance",
      "trust_tier": "IBT",
      "permissions": ["approve_l3", "override_decision"]
    }
  ]
}
```

**Test Agent Calls:**
```python
# Test Sentinel
response = mcp_client.call_tool("audit_code", {
    "code": "print('Hello, World!')",
    "context": "test"
})

# Verify response
assert response["status"] == "success"
```

**Deliverable:** All 4 agents operational and responding

#### A5: Team Onboarding (3h)

**Training Session Agenda:**

**Part 1: Overview (30 min)**
- What is Q-DNA / QoreLogic?
- L1/L2/L3 risk grading system
- HITL approval workflow
- Trust scoring basics

**Part 2: Hands-On (90 min)**
- Install MCP client
- Connect to QoreLogic server
- Submit L1 code for audit
- Trigger L3 approval flow
- Review audit results in dashboard
- Interpret trust scores

**Part 3: Q&A (60 min)**
- Common questions
- Troubleshooting
- Escalation paths
- Feedback collection

**Materials:**
- [ ] Quick-start guide
- [ ] Dashboard walkthrough
- [ ] Troubleshooting FAQ
- [ ] Slack channel invitation (#qorelogic-pilot)

**Deliverable:** Team trained and ready to use QoreLogic

#### A6: Create Deployment Runbook (1h)

**Runbook Sections:**
1. Pre-deployment checklist
2. Deployment steps (detailed)
3. Verification procedures
4. Rollback plan
5. Common issues and fixes
6. Contact information

**Deliverable:** `DEPLOYMENT_RUNBOOK.md`

### Agent Specification

```yaml
agent_type: platform-engineer
description: Expert in deployment automation, infrastructure as code, and developer platform engineering
skills:
  - Docker containerization
  - CI/CD pipeline configuration
  - Infrastructure provisioning
  - Service orchestration
  - Health check implementation
  - Runbook creation
tools:
  - Read
  - Write
  - Edit
  - Bash
  - Glob
  - Grep
success_criteria:
  - MCP server deployed and operational
  - All agents configured and responding
  - Team onboarded successfully
  - Deployment runbook complete
```

---

## Track B: Monitoring & Observability (SRE)

**Agent:** `sre-engineer`
**Duration:** Day 1-7 (continuous, ~6 hours/week)
**Dependencies:** Track A (deployment)
**Status:** dY"< Ready

### Objectives

1. Monitor production metrics continuously
2. Track SLO compliance
3. Generate daily status reports
4. Alert on anomalies
5. Weekly usage report

### Tasks

| ID | Task | Schedule | Deliverable |
|:---|:-----|:---------|:------------|
| B1 | Configure Grafana for pilot | Day 1 | Dashboard live |
| B2 | Set up alert routing | Day 1 | Alerts to Slack |
| B3 | Daily metric review | Daily (9am) | Status update |
| B4 | SLO compliance tracking | Daily | SLO dashboard |
| B5 | Weekly usage report | Day 5 | Report published |

### Detailed Task Breakdown

#### B1: Configure Grafana for Pilot (2h)

**Dashboard Panels:**

1. **System Health**
   - Uptime percentage (rolling 24h)
   - Request rate (req/s)
   - Error rate (%)
   - P50/P95/P99 latency

2. **Audit Metrics**
   - Audits completed (count)
   - Catch rate (%)
   - False positive rate (%)
   - L3 escalations (count)

3. **Trust Engine**
   - Trust score distribution
   - Stage transitions (CBT/KBT/IBT)
   - Penalty events
   - Probation status

4. **Infrastructure**
   - CPU usage (%)
   - Memory usage (MB)
   - Database size (MB)
   - Queue depth

**Import Dashboard:**
```bash
# Load dashboard configuration
curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/api/dashboards/db \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d @grafana_dashboard.json
```

**Deliverable:** Live Grafana dashboard accessible to team

#### B2: Set up Alert Routing (1h)

**Alert Channels:**

**Slack Integration:**
```yaml
# alertmanager.yml
route:
  receiver: 'slack-qorelogic-pilot'
  routes:
    - match:
        severity: critical
      receiver: 'slack-qorelogic-critical'
      continue: true

receivers:
  - name: 'slack-qorelogic-pilot'
    slack_configs:
      - api_url: 'SLACK_WEBHOOK_URL'
        channel: '#qorelogic-pilot'
        title: 'QoreLogic Alert'
        text: '{{ range .Alerts }}{{ .Annotations.description }}{{ end }}'

  - name: 'slack-qorelogic-critical'
    slack_configs:
      - api_url: 'SLACK_WEBHOOK_URL'
        channel: '#qorelogic-critical'
        title: 'dYs" CRITICAL ALERT'
```

**Test Alert:**
```bash
# Trigger test alert
curl -X POST http://localhost:9093/api/v1/alerts \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '[{"labels":{"alertname":"TestAlert","severity":"warning"}}]'
```

**Deliverable:** Alerts routing to Slack successfully

#### B3: Daily Metric Review (15 min/day)

**Daily Standup Checklist:**


- How clear is the L1/L2/L3 grading system? (1-10)
- How often did QoreLogic help you catch issues? (Always/Often/Sometimes/Rarely/Never)

**2. Performance (4 questions)**
- Was QoreLogic's response time acceptable? (Yes/No/Sometimes)
- Did you experience any downtime? (Yes/No)
- If yes, how long? (< 5 min / 5-30 min / > 30 min)
- Did performance impact your workflow? (Yes/No)

**3. Accuracy (5 questions)**
- How often did QoreLogic correctly identify issues? (%)
- How many false positives did you encounter?
- Were false positives easy to override?
- Did QoreLogic miss any issues you later discovered?
- How helpful were the audit explanations? (1-10)

**4. Usability (5 questions)**
- Dashboard clarity (1-10)
- Error message helpfulness (1-10)
- L3 approval workflow clarity (1-10)
- Documentation quality (1-10)
- Ease of integration (1-10)

**5. Open Feedback (3 questions)**

- What frustrated you the most?
- What one feature would you add?

**Agent:** `debugger`

### Incident Severity Levels

| Priority | Description | Response Time | Fix Deadline | Example |
|:---------|:------------|:--------------|:-------------|:--------|
| **P0** | Critical - System down | <1h | 24h | MCP server crash, data loss |
| **P1** | High - Major functionality broken | <4h | 1 week | L3 approval fails, metrics down |
| **P2** | Medium - Minor functionality issue | <24h | 2 weeks | Dashboard rendering bug, slow query |
| **P3** | Low - Cosmetic or enhancement | <1 week | Backlog | UI tweak, documentation typo |

### Common Issues & Fixes

**Issue 1: MCP Server Unresponsive**
```bash
# Symptom: Health check fails
curl http://localhost:9090/health
# Connection refused

# Diagnosis
ps aux | grep qorelogic
# No process found

# Fix
cd Q-DNA/local_fortress
python qorelogic.py

# Prevention
# Add systemd service or Docker container
```

**Issue 2: Database Locked**
```python
# Symptom: sqlite3.OperationalError: database is locked

# Diagnosis
# Multiple processes accessing SQLite

# Fix
# Add connection pooling with timeout
conn = sqlite3.connect(
    "ledger/qdna_soa_ledger.db",
    timeout=30.0,
    check_same_thread=False
)

# Prevention
# Use WAL mode
cursor.execute("PRAGMA journal_mode=WAL")
```

**Issue 3: High Latency**
```bash
# Symptom: P95 latency >1s

# Diagnosis
# Check Prometheus metrics
curl http://localhost:9090/metrics | grep duration

# Likely causes:
# - Regex not pre-compiled
# - Missing database index
# - Synchronous I/O

# Fix
# See performance optimization playbook
```

## Rollback Plan

If critical issues arise during Week 4:

### Triggers for Rollback

- **P0 Incident:** System down >4 hours
- **Data Loss:** Any corruption of ledger database
- **Security Breach:** Unauthorized access detected
- **User Revolt:** Pilot team requests shutdown
- **SLA Violation:** Uptime <95% after Day 3

### Rollback Procedure

**Phase 1: Immediate Actions (< 1 hour)**
1. Disable QoreLogic MCP server
   ```bash
   # Stop server
   pkill -f qorelogic.py

   # Verify stopped
   ps aux | grep qorelogic
   ```

2. Notify pilot team
   ```markdown
   Subject: QoreLogic Pilot - Temporary Shutdown

   We've temporarily disabled QoreLogic due to [issue].
   Your workflow is unaffected - proceed without QoreLogic.

   We're investigating and will provide updates every 2 hours.
   ```

3. Document failure mode
   ```markdown
   # Rollback Incident

   **Date:** YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM
   **Trigger:** [What caused rollback]
   **Impact:** [Who/what was affected]
   **Status:** Investigating
   ```

**Phase 2: Analysis (1-4 hours)**
1. Review logs and metrics
   ```bash
   # Export logs for analysis
   cp logs/qorelogic.log logs/incident_$(date +%Y%m%d).log

   # Query Prometheus for metrics
   curl -G http://localhost:9090/api/v1/query_range \
     --data-urlencode 'query=qorelogic_errors_total' \
     > metrics_export.json
   ```

2. Identify root cause
3. Assess impact and risk

**Phase 3: Decision (within 4 hours of rollback)**

**Option A: Fix Forward**
- If fix is simple (<4 hours)
- High confidence in fix
- No data loss risk

**Option B: Rollback**
- If complex issue requiring redesign
- Low confidence in quick fix
- Risk of further damage

**Option C: Partial Rollback**
- Disable specific features
- Keep core system running
- Isolate problematic component

**Phase 4: Communication**
- Update stakeholders every 2 hours
- Create incident post-mortem
- Schedule retrospective
- Document lessons learned

### Rollback Checklist

- [ ] Server stopped
- [ ] Team notified
- [ ] Incident logged
- [ ] Logs exported
- [ ] Metrics captured
- [ ] Root cause identified
- [ ] Decision made (A/B/C)
- [ ] Stakeholders updated
- [ ] Post-mortem scheduled

## Risk Matrix

| Risk | Probability | Impact | Mitigation |
|:-----|:-----------|:-------|:-----------|
| **Pilot deployment issues** | Medium | High | Extensive Week 3 testing, rollback plan ready |
| **User adoption resistance** | Medium | Medium | Excellent onboarding, UX research upfront |
| **False positive rate in production** | Low | Medium | Heuristics proven in benchmarks, L3 approval safety net |
| **Performance degradation** | Low | Medium | Baselines established, continuous monitoring |
| **Missing edge cases** | Medium | Low | Shadow Genome for failure analysis, rapid iteration |
| **Data corruption** | Very Low | Critical | Merkle chain integrity, daily backups |
| **Security breach** | Very Low | Critical | Ed25519 signatures, audit trail |

# Incident Response Playbook

**Version:** 1.0
**Last Updated:** 2025-12-25
**Owner:** incident-responder (GLM 4.7)

## Overview

This playbook provides step-by-step remediation procedures for each alert defined in `alerts.yml`. When an alert fires, follow the corresponding playbook immediately.

## Incident Severity Levels

| Severity      | Response Time | Notification Channel |
| ------------- | ------------- | -------------------- |
| Critical (P0) | < 5 minutes   | PagerDuty / SMS      |
| Warning (P1)  | < 30 minutes  | Slack #incidents     |

---

## Critical Incidents (P0)

### Playbook: Service Down

**Alert:** `ServiceDown`  
**Severity:** Critical  
**Trigger:** `up{job="qorelogic_server"} == 0 for 1m`

#### Immediate Actions (0-5 minutes)

1. **Verify Service Status**

   ```bash
   # Check if process is running
   ps aux | grep qorelogic

   # Check service status
   systemctl status qorelogic
   ```

2. **Check Application Logs**

   ```bash
   # View last 50 error logs
   journalctl -u qorelogic -n 50 --no-pager | grep -i error

   # Or if using file logs
   tail -n 100 /var/log/qorelogic/app.log | grep -i error
   ```

3. **Check System Resources**

   ```bash
   # Check disk space
   df -h

   # Check memory
   free -h

   # Check CPU
   top -n 1 | head -20
   ```

#### Remediation Steps

**If process crashed:**

1. Restart the service:
   ```bash
   systemctl restart qorelogic
   ```
2. Monitor startup logs for errors:
   ```bash
   journalctl -u qorelogic -f
   ```

**If out of disk space:**

1. Identify large files:
   ```bash
   du -sh /var/log/qorelogic/* | sort -rh | head -10
   ```
2. Rotate or compress old logs:
   ```bash
   logrotate -f /etc/logrotate.d/qorelogic
   ```

**If out of memory (OOM killed):**

1. Check dmesg for OOM events:
   ```bash
   dmesg | grep -i "killed process"
   ```
2. Increase swap or add memory
3. Review memory usage patterns in Grafana

#### Verification

```bash
# Verify service is up
curl -f http://localhost:8080/health || echo "Service still down"

# Check metrics endpoint
curl http://localhost:9090/metrics | grep up
```

**Criteria for Resolution:** Service returns HTTP 200 on `/health` endpoint and `up{job="qorelogic_server"}` == 1

#### Escalation

If service does not recover within 10 minutes:

- Page on-call engineering lead
- Create incident ticket in Jira
- Notify stakeholders via Slack

---

### Playbook: High Latency

**Alert:** `HighLatency`  
**Severity:** Critical  
**Trigger:** `P95 audit_latency_seconds > 1.0s for 5m`

#### Immediate Actions (0-5 minutes)

1. **Confirm Latency Spike**

   ```bash
   # Check current P95 latency
   curl -s http://localhost:9090/metrics | grep audit_latency_seconds
   ```

2. **Check System Load**

   ```bash
   # CPU usage
   top -bn1 | head -20

   # I/O wait
   iostat -x 1 5
   ```

3. **Check Database Performance**

   ```bash
   # Active connections
   sqlite3 qorelogic.db "PRAGMA database_list;"

   # Check for long-running queries (if using PostgreSQL)
   # SELECT pid, now() - query_start as duration, query FROM pg_stat_activity WHERE state = 'active';
   ```

#### Remediation Steps

**If high CPU:**

1. Identify CPU-intensive processes:
   ```bash
   ps aux --sort=-%cpu | head -10
   ```
2. If audit process is consuming CPU, check for:
   - Regex compilation issues (should be pre-compiled)
   - Infinite loops in heuristic patterns
3. Restart service if necessary:
   ```bash
   systemctl restart qorelogic
   ```

**If high I/O:**

1. Check disk I/O:
   ```bash
   iotop -o
   ```
2. If database is bottleneck:
   - Verify indexes exist on `soa_ledger.timestamp` and `soa_ledger.agent_did`
   - Run `ANALYZE` on SQLite database:
     ```bash
     sqlite3 qorelogic.db "ANALYZE;"
     ```

**If high network latency:**

1. Check network connectivity:
   ```bash
   ping -c 10 8.8.8.8
   traceroute 8.8.8.8
   ```
2. Check for external API calls that might be slow

#### Verification

```bash
# Run a test audit
curl -X POST http://localhost:8080/audit \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"code": "print(\"test\")"}'

# Verify latency is < 1s
```

**Criteria for Resolution:** P95 latency < 1.0s sustained for 10 minutes

#### Escalation

If latency does not improve within 15 minutes:

- Notify performance engineering team
- Review recent code deployments
- Consider traffic throttling if necessary

---

### Playbook: High Error Rate

**Alert:** `HighErrorRate`  
**Severity:** Critical  
**Trigger:** `Error rate > 1% for 5m`

#### Immediate Actions (0-5 minutes)

1. **Check Error Metrics**

   ```bash
   # Get error breakdown by verdict
   curl -s http://localhost:9090/metrics | grep audit_total
   ```

2. **Review Recent Error Logs**

   ```bash
   # Get last 100 error logs
   journalctl -u qorelogic -n 100 --no-pager | grep -i error

   # Or from file logs
   tail -n 200 /var/log/qorelogic/app.log | jq 'select(.level == "ERROR")'
   ```

3. **Check Database Integrity**
   ```bash
   # SQLite integrity check
   sqlite3 qorelogic.db "PRAGMA integrity_check;"
   ```

#### Remediation Steps

**If database corruption detected:**

1. Stop the service:
   ```bash
   systemctl stop qorelogic
   ```
2. Restore from most recent backup:
   ```bash
   cp /backups/qorelogic.db.backup /var/lib/qorelogic/qorelogic.db
   ```
3. Start service:
   ```bash
   systemctl start qorelogic
   ```

**If application errors:**

1. Identify error pattern from logs
2. Common issues:
   - **UNIQUE constraint violations:** Check for duplicate DIDs
   - **Regex compilation errors:** Verify regex patterns are valid
   - **Missing dependencies:** Check import errors in logs
3. If recent deployment caused errors:
   ```bash
   # Rollback to previous version
   git revert HEAD
   systemctl restart qorelogic
   ```

**If out of resources:**

1. Check disk space (see Service Down playbook)
2. Check memory (see High Memory playbook)

#### Verification

```bash
# Run 10 test audits and verify all succeed
for i in {1..10}; do
  curl -X POST http://localhost:8080/audit \
    -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    -d '{"code": "print(\"test\")"}'
done
```

**Criteria for Resolution:** Error rate < 1% sustained for 10 minutes

#### Escalation

If error rate does not decrease within 15 minutes:

- Page on-call engineering lead
- Review recent code changes
- Consider disabling non-critical features

---

## Warning Incidents (P1)

### Playbook: High Database Latency

**Alert:** `HighDatabaseLatency`  
**Severity:** Warning  
**Trigger:** `P95 db_query_duration_seconds > 500ms for 10m`

#### Actions

1. **Check Query Performance**

   ```bash
   # Check slow queries in logs
   grep "slow query" /var/log/qorelogic/app.log
   ```

2. **Verify Indexes**

   ```bash
   sqlite3 qorelogic.db "PRAGMA index_list('soa_ledger');"
   ```

3. **Run Database Maintenance**
   ```bash
   sqlite3 qorelogic.db "VACUUM;"
   sqlite3 qorelogic.db "ANALYZE;"
   ```

**Criteria for Resolution:** P95 DB latency < 500ms sustained for 15 minutes

---

### Playbook: High Memory Usage

**Alert:** `HighMemoryUsage`  
**Severity:** Warning  
**Trigger:** `Memory usage > 80% for 15m`

#### Actions

1. **Check Memory Breakdown**

   ```bash
   # Process memory
   ps aux --sort=-%mem | head -10

   # System memory
   free -h
   ```

2. **Identify Memory Leaks**

   ```bash
   # Check for growing memory over time
   watch -n 10 'ps aux | grep qorelogic'
   ```

3. **Restart Service (if needed)**
   ```bash
   systemctl restart qorelogic
   ```

**Criteria for Resolution:** Memory usage < 80% sustained for 15 minutes

---

### Playbook: High Trust Update Latency

**Alert:** `HighTrustUpdateLatency`  
**Severity:** Warning  
**Trigger:** `P95 trust_update_duration_seconds > 200ms for 10m`

#### Actions

1. **Check Trust Score Calculation**

   ```bash
   # Review trust update logs
   grep "trust_update" /var/log/qorelogic/app.log | tail -50
   ```

2. **Verify Trust Score Cache**

   ```bash
   # Check if LRU cache is effective
   # Review code for functools.lru_cache usage
   ```

3. **Restart Service (if needed)**
   ```bash
   systemctl restart qorelogic
   ```

**Criteria for Resolution:** P95 trust update latency < 200ms sustained for 15 minutes

---

### Playbook: Low Audit Throughput

**Alert:** `LowAuditThroughput`  
**Severity:** Warning  
**Trigger:** `Rate < 0.1 req/s for 15m`

#### Actions

1. **Check if Service is Idle**

   ```bash
   # Check request metrics
   curl -s http://localhost:9090/metrics | grep audit_total
   ```

2. **Verify Service Health**

   ```bash
   curl http://localhost:8080/health
   ```

3. **Check for Queue Backlog** (if using message queue)
   ```bash
   # Check queue depth
   # (implementation-specific)
   ```

**Note:** Low throughput may be normal during off-peak hours. Only investigate if unexpected.

**Criteria for Resolution:** Throughput returns to expected baseline or confirmed as normal operation

---

After resolving a P0 incident, complete this post-mortem within 5 business days.

# Alert Routing Configuration

**Version:** 1.0  
**Last Updated:** 2025-12-26  
**Owner:** SRE Team

---

## Overview

This document defines the alert routing strategy for the QoreLogic system. It specifies how alerts are classified, routed to appropriate teams, and escalated based on severity and duration.

---

## Alert Severity Levels

### P0 - Critical (Immediate Action Required)

**Definition:** Service is down or severely degraded, impacting all users.

**Response Time:** < 5 minutes  
**Escalation:** Immediate page to on-call engineer  
**Examples:**

- ServiceDown: QoreLogic service is completely unavailable
- HighLatency: P95 latency > 1.0s for 5+ minutes
- HighErrorRate: Error rate > 1% for 5+ minutes

### P1 - High Priority (Urgent Attention Required)

**Definition:** Service is degraded but partially functional, impacting significant user base.

**Response Time:** < 30 minutes  
**Escalation:** Slack notification to platform team  
**Examples:**

- HighDatabaseLatency: DB P95 latency > 500ms for 10+ minutes
- HighMemoryUsage: Memory > 80% for 15+ minutes
- HighTrustUpdateLatency: Trust update P95 > 200ms for 10+ minutes

### P2 - Medium Priority (Attention Required)

**Definition:** Service is functional but showing warning signs, potential future impact.

**Response Time:** < 2 hours  
**Escalation:** Daily standup discussion  
**Examples:**

- LowAuditThroughput: Throughput < 0.1 req/s for 15+ minutes
- Gradual performance degradation
- Resource usage trending upward

### P3 - Low Priority (Informational)

**Definition:** Informational alerts for monitoring purposes, no immediate action required.

**Response Time:** Next business day  
**Escalation:** Weekly review  
**Examples:**

- Scheduled maintenance reminders
- Capacity planning warnings
- Performance trend analysis

---

## Alert Routing Matrix

| Alert Name             | Severity | Primary Team | Secondary Team | Channel                | Escalation Path                  |
| ---------------------- | -------- | ------------ | -------------- | ---------------------- | -------------------------------- |
| ServiceDown            | P0       | Platform     | DevOps         | PagerDuty              | On-call Æ’+' Engineering Lead Æ’+' CTO |
| HighLatency            | P0       | Platform     | Performance    | PagerDuty              | On-call Æ’+' Engineering Lead Æ’+' CTO |
| HighErrorRate          | P0       | Platform     | DevOps         | PagerDuty              | On-call Æ’+' Engineering Lead Æ’+' CTO |
| HighDatabaseLatency    | P1       | Platform     | DBA            | Slack #alerts-platform | Team Lead Æ’+' Engineering Manager  |
| HighMemoryUsage        | P1       | Platform     | DevOps         | Slack #alerts-platform | Team Lead Æ’+' Engineering Manager  |
| HighTrustUpdateLatency | P1       | Platform     | Trust Team     | Slack #alerts-platform | Team Lead Æ’+' Engineering Manager  |
| LowAuditThroughput     | P2       | Platform     | Product        | Slack #alerts-platform | Daily Standup                    |
| DiskSpaceWarning       | P2       | DevOps       | Platform       | Slack #alerts-devops   | Team Lead                        |
| BackupFailure          | P1       | DevOps       | Platform       | Slack #alerts-devops   | Team Lead Æ’+' Engineering Manager  |

---

## On-Call Rotation

### Primary On-Call

**Schedule:** Weekly rotation, Monday 00:00 UTC to Sunday 23:59 UTC  
**Handoff:** Sunday 23:00 UTC - Monday 01:00 UTC (2-hour overlap)  
**Responsibilities:**

- Respond to P0 alerts within 5 minutes
- Acknowledge all P0 and P1 alerts
- Coordinate incident response for P0 incidents
- Document all incidents in incident tracker

### Secondary On-Call (Backup)

**Schedule:** Same as primary  
**Responsibilities:**

- Backup for primary on-call
- Take over if primary is unavailable
- Assist with incident resolution

### On-Call Escalation

1. **Primary On-Call** - First responder
2. **Secondary On-Call** - Backup (if primary unavailable after 15 minutes)
3. **Engineering Lead** - Escalation after 30 minutes
4. **CTO** - Escalation after 1 hour for critical incidents

---

## Alert Channels

### PagerDuty (P0 Alerts)

**Configuration:**

- Service: QoreLogic-Production
- Escalation Policy: Primary Æ’+' Secondary Æ’+' Engineering Lead Æ’+' CTO
- Notification Rules:
  - SMS: Immediate
  - Phone call: After 5 minutes if not acknowledged
  - Email: Immediate

**Alerts Routed:**

- ServiceDown
- HighLatency
- HighErrorRate

### Slack (P1-P3 Alerts)

**Channels:**

- `#alerts-platform` - Platform team alerts (P1, P2)
- `#alerts-devops` - DevOps alerts (P1, P2)
- `#alerts-trust` - Trust system alerts (P1, P2)
- `#alerts-info` - Informational alerts (P3)

**Notification Rules:**

- P1: @channel mention
- P2: @here mention
- P3: No mention, just message

### Email (All Alerts)

**Recipients:**

- P0: oncall@qorelogic.ai, platform-team@qorelogic.ai
- P1: platform-team@qorelogic.ai
- P2: platform-team@qorelogic.ai
- P3: platform-team@qorelogic.ai (daily digest)

---

## Alert Suppression Rules

### Maintenance Windows

**Scheduled Maintenance:**

- Alerts suppressed during scheduled maintenance windows
- Maintenance window must be declared at least 24 hours in advance
- Post-maintenance verification required

**Emergency Maintenance:**

- Alerts can be suppressed with engineering lead approval
- Must document reason and expected duration
- Post-incident review required

### Known Issues

**Temporary Suppression:**

- Maximum 24 hours for known issues being investigated
- Requires incident ticket reference
- Must be reviewed daily

**Permanent Suppression:**

- Requires engineering manager approval
- Must document reason and alternative monitoring
- Quarterly review required

---

## Alert Deduplication

### Grouping Rules

**Time Window:** 5 minutes  
**Grouping By:**

- Alert name
- Severity
- Affected service/instance

**Example:**

- Multiple ServiceDown alerts for same instance within 5 minutes Æ’+' 1 notification
- Multiple HighLatency alerts for different instances Æ’+' Multiple notifications

### Throttling

**Maximum Notifications:**

- P0: No throttling
- P1: Maximum 1 notification per 10 minutes per alert
- P2: Maximum 1 notification per 30 minutes per alert
- P3: Daily digest only

---

## Alert Acknowledgment Workflow

### P0 Alerts

1. **Alert Fired** Æ’+' PagerDuty notification
2. **Acknowledge** Æ’+' Within 5 minutes
3. **Investigation** Æ’+' Start immediately
4. **Update** Æ’+' Every 15 minutes until resolved
5. **Resolve** Æ’+' When issue is fixed
6. **Post-Incident Review** Æ’+' Within 24 hours

### P1 Alerts

1. **Alert Fired** Æ’+' Slack notification
2. **Acknowledge** Æ’+' Within 30 minutes
3. **Investigation** Æ’+' Start within 1 hour
4. **Update** Æ’+' Every hour until resolved
5. **Resolve** Æ’+' When issue is fixed
6. **Review** Æ’+' Next daily standup

### P2 Alerts

1. **Alert Fired** Æ’+' Slack notification
2. **Acknowledge** Æ’+' Within 2 hours
3. **Investigation** Æ’+' Start within 4 hours
4. **Resolve** Æ’+' When issue is fixed
5. **Review** Æ’+' Next daily standup

---

## Escalation Procedures

### Automatic Escalation

**P0 Alerts:**

- 5 minutes: Page primary on-call
- 15 minutes: Page secondary on-call (if primary not acknowledged)
- 30 minutes: Page engineering lead
- 1 hour: Page CTO

**P1 Alerts:**

- 30 minutes: Slack @channel
- 2 hours: Escalate to engineering manager
- 4 hours: Escalate to engineering lead

### Manual Escalation

**When to Escalate:**

- Unable to resolve within expected timeframe
- Issue is more severe than initially assessed
- Need additional resources or expertise
- Impact is expanding to more users

**Escalation Process:**

1. Document current status in incident ticket
2. Contact next level in escalation chain
3. Provide clear summary of issue and actions taken
4. Hand off incident ownership if appropriate

---

## Alert Quality Metrics

### Metrics to Track

| Metric                      | Target          | Measurement                   |
| --------------------------- | --------------- | ----------------------------- |
| Alert Response Time (P0)    | < 5 minutes     | Time fired to acknowledged    |
| Alert Response Time (P1)    | < 30 minutes    | Time fired to acknowledged    |
| False Positive Rate         | < 5%            | False alerts / total alerts   |
| Mean Time to Resolve (MTTR) | < 1 hour (P0)   | Time acknowledged to resolved |
| Alert Fatigue Score         | < 10 alerts/day | Total alerts / day            |

### Weekly Review

**Review Items:**

- Alert volume by severity
- False positive analysis
- Response time trends
- MTTR trends
- Alert fatigue assessment
- Tuning recommendations

**Action Items:**

- Adjust alert thresholds if needed
- Suppress noisy alerts
- Add new alerts for emerging issues
- Remove obsolete alerts

---

## Integration with Incident Management

### Alert Æ’+' Incident Creation

**Automatic Creation:**

- P0 alerts automatically create incident ticket
- P1 alerts create incident ticket if not resolved in 1 hour
- P2 alerts create incident ticket if not resolved in 4 hours

**Incident Metadata:**

- Alert name and severity
- Time fired
- Affected components
- Initial diagnosis (if available)
- Assigned team

### Incident Æ’+' Alert Updates

**Status Updates:**

- When incident is acknowledged, update alert status
- When incident is resolved, resolve associated alerts
- When incident is escalated, update alert routing

---

## Testing and Validation

### Alert Testing

**Weekly Tests:**

- Test P0 alert routing (scheduled maintenance window)
- Verify PagerDuty integration
- Test Slack notifications
- Validate escalation paths

**Monthly Tests:**

- Full failover test (primary Æ’+' secondary)
- Test all alert rules
- Validate suppression rules
- Review alert quality metrics

### Alert Drills

**Quarterly Drills:**

- Simulate major incident
- Test on-call response
- Practice escalation procedures
- Review incident documentation

---

## Configuration Files

### AlertManager Configuration

```yaml
# alertmanager.yml
global:
  resolve_timeout: 5m

route:
  receiver: "default"
  group_by: ["alertname", "severity"]
  group_wait: 10s
  group_interval: 10s
  repeat_interval: 12h

  routes:
    # P0 Alerts - PagerDuty
    - match:
        severity: critical
      receiver: "pagerduty-critical"
      continue: false

    # P1 Alerts - Slack
    - match:
        severity: warning
      receiver: "slack-platform"
      continue: false

    # P2/P3 Alerts - Email
    - match:
        severity: info
      receiver: "email-info"
      continue: false

receivers:
  - name: "pagerduty-critical"
    pagerduty_configs:
      - service_key: "<PAGERDUTY_SERVICE_KEY>"
        severity: "critical"

  - name: "slack-platform"
    slack_configs:
      - api_url: "<SLACK_WEBHOOK_URL>"
        channel: "#alerts-platform"
        title: "{{ .GroupLabels.alertname }}"
        text: "{{ range .Alerts }}{{ .Annotations.description }}{{ end }}"

  - name: "email-info"
    email_configs:
      - to: "platform-team@qorelogic.ai"
        from: "alerts@qorelogic.ai"
        headers:
          Subject: "[INFO] {{ .GroupLabels.alertname }}"
```

---

## Change Management

### Alert Rule Changes

**Process:**

1. Submit change request with justification
2. Review by SRE team
3. Test in staging environment
4. Schedule deployment (preferably during low-traffic periods)
5. Monitor for 24 hours after deployment
6. Document change in changelog

### Rollback Procedure

**When to Rollback:**

- High false positive rate after change
- Missed critical alerts
- Unexpected alert volume
- Negative impact on team productivity

**Rollback Steps:**

1. Identify problematic change
2. Revert to previous configuration
3. Verify alert routing is working
4. Document incident
5. Schedule review of change

---

## Appendix: Contact Information

### Emergency Contacts

| Role                | Name   | Phone   | Email   |
| ------------------- | ------ | ------- | ------- |
| CTO                 | [Name] | [Phone] | [Email] |
| Engineering Lead    | [Name] | [Phone] | [Email] |
| Engineering Manager | [Name] | [Phone] | [Email] |
| SRE Lead            | [Name] | [Phone] | [Email] |

### Team Channels

| Team     | Slack Channel  | Email                      |
| -------- | -------------- | -------------------------- |
| Platform | #platform-team | platform-team@qorelogic.ai |
| DevOps   | #devops-team   | devops-team@qorelogic.ai   |
| Trust    | #trust-team    | trust-team@qorelogic.ai    |

---

---
